docs.lead_paragraph: A former funeral home manager and his wife were arrested yesterday and charged with illegally collecting more than $20,000 in Medicaid benefits, the authorities said. The couple, Abraham Levy, 36, and Miriam Levy, 37, of Brooklyn, lied about their income and neglected to tell welfare officials about a bank account into which they deposited more than $1.5 million in less than two years, according to the state welfare inspector general, Brian P. Sanvidge. In 2003, the Levys, who both worked at Shomrei Hadas Chapels, a funeral home in Borough Park, underreported their income on their Medicaid applications by more than $105,000, Mr. Sanvidge said. They were charged with welfare fraud and grand larceny and face up to seven years in prison if convicted of the top fraud charge. ANDY NEWMAN

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Couple Charged With Medicaid Fraud

docs.abstract: Abraham and Miriam Levy are charged with illegally collecting more than $20,000 in Medicaid benefits after underreporting their income by more than $105,000; were employed as funeral directors at Shmrei Hadas Chapels in Borough Park section of Brooklyn; also neglected to tell welfare officials that they had deposited more than $1.5 million into bank accounts over two-year period (S)

byline.original: By ANDY NEWMAN; Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Health Care Plan So Simple, Even Stephen Colbert Couldn't Simplify It,'' by Robert H. Frank (Economic Scene, Feb. 15), is right to condemn a health care system that has a profit motive in place at the top.
docs.abstract: Letter from Allan Zelikovic, director of medical malpractice department at Weitz & Luxenberg, contends even Canada is moving away from socialized medicine, recognizing that good care costs money; says deficiencies in either system cannot be reduced to administrative costs (Feb 15 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     ''A Health Care Plan So Simple, Even Stephen Colbert Couldn't Simplify It,'' by Robert H. Frank (Economic Scene, Feb. 15), is right to condemn a health care system that has a profit motive in place at the top.
